panels.description: Average Latency of top $TopResources volumes.

targets.expr: avg(topk($TopResources, volume_avg_latency{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",style!="flexgroup_constituent"} * on (datacenter, cluster, svm, volume) group_left(node) volume_labels{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",tags=~".*$Tag.*"}))

volume_new_status{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",style!="flexgroup_constituent"} * on (datacenter, cluster, svm, volume) group_left(node) volume_labels{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",tags=~".*$Tag.*"}

volume_size_total{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",style!="flexgroup_constituent"} * on (datacenter, cluster, svm, volume) group_left(node) volume_labels{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",tags=~".*$Tag.*"}

volume_size_used_percent{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",style!="flexgroup_constituent"} * on (datacenter, cluster, svm, volume) group_left(node) volume_labels{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",tags=~".*$Tag.*"}

volume_sis_dedup_saved{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",style!="flexgroup_constituent"} * on (datacenter, cluster, svm, volume) group_left(node) volume_labels{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",tags=~".*$Tag.*"}

volume_sis_compress_saved{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",style!="flexgroup_constituent"} * on (datacenter, cluster, svm, volume) group_left(node) volume_labels{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",tags=~".*$Tag.*"}

volume_sis_dedup_saved+volume_sis_compress_saved{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",style!="flexgroup_constituent"} * on (datacenter, cluster, svm, volume) group_left(node) volume_labels{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",tags=~".*$Tag.*"}

volume_space_physical_used{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",style!="flexgroup_constituent"} * on (datacenter, cluster, svm, volume) group_left(node) volume_labels{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume",tags=~".*$Tag.*"}

panels.title: Volume IOPs per Type
Performance

panels.description: This panel displays the top k volumes with the highest I/O density within the selected time range. I/O density is calculated as the average number of I/O operations (IOPS) per terabyte of logical used space. Volumes with high I/O density are typically more active and may be critical for performance-sensitive applications.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by IO Density (IOPs/TiB)

panels.description: This panel displays the bottom k volumes with the lowest I/O density over the selected time range, excluding any volumes with average IOPS below 50. I/O density is calculated as the average IOPS per terabyte of logical used space. These volumes are active but have relatively low I/O activity compared to their used capacity.
panels.title: Bottom $TopResources Volumes by IO Density (IOPs/TiB)
I/O Density

options.content:
This panel requires Workload/QOS counter templates. They are disabled by default because they typically slow down data collection due to a high number of metrics. Two actions are required to use this panel:
1. If you are using ZapiPerf Collector, then On Harvest, You must enable the Workload/QOS counters in $HARVEST/conf/zapiperf/default.yaml.
2. If you are using RestPerf Collector, then On Harvest, You must enable the Workload/QOS counters in $HARVEST/conf/restperf/default.yaml.
Refer ONTAP Performance - Resolution Guide https://kb.netapp.com/Advice_and_Troubleshooting/Data_Storage_Software/ONTAP_OS/ONTAP_9_Performance_-_Resolution_Guide

panels.title: Important Information on Top Volume QoS Resource Latency Graphs

panels.description: This is the average response time for read requests that were initiated by the workload.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by QoS Volume Read Latency

panels.description: This is the average response time for write requests that were initiated by the workload.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by QoS Volume Write Latency

panels.description: This is the rate of this workload's read operations that completed during the measurement interval.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by QoS Volume Read IOPS

panels.description: This is the workload's write operations that completed during the measurement interval; measured per second.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by QoS Volume Write IOPS

panels.description: This is the amount of data read per second from the filer by the workload.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by QoS Volume Read Throughput

panels.description: This is the amount of data written per second to the filer by the workload.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by QoS Volume Write Throughput

panels.description: This is the percentage of reads, performed on behalf of the workload, that were sequential.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by QoS Volume Sequential Reads

panels.description: This is the percentage of writes, performed on behalf of the workload, that were sequential. This counter is only available on platforms with more than 4GB of NVRAM.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by QoS Volume Sequential Writes
QoS

options.content:
This panel requires Workload/QOS counter templates. They are disabled by default because they typically slow down data collection due to a high number of metrics. Two actions are required to use this panel:
1. If you are using ZapiPerf Collector, then On Harvest, You must enable the Workload/QOS counters in $HARVEST/conf/zapiperf/default.yaml.
2. If you are using RestPerf Collector, then On Harvest, You must enable the Workload/QOS counters in $HARVEST/conf/restperf/default.yaml.
Refer ONTAP Performance - Resolution Guide https://kb.netapp.com/Advice_and_Troubleshooting/Data_Storage_Software/ONTAP_OS/ONTAP_9_Performance_-_Resolution_Guide

panels.title: Important Information on Top Volume QoS Resource Latency Graphs

panels.description:
`Note:` Typically these latencies only apply to SAN not NAS.

Represents the wait time of I/O requests by the external networking protocols on the cluster. The wait time is time spent waiting for transfer ready transactions to finish before the cluster can respond to an I/O request. If the network component is in contention, it means high wait time at the protocol layer is impacting the latency of one or more workloads.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Latency from Network

panels.description: Represents the throughput maximum (ceiling) setting of the storage Quality of Service (QoS) policy group assigned to the workload. If the policy group component is in contention, it means all workloads in the policy group are being throttled by the set throughput limit, which is impacting the latency of one or more of those workloads.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Latency from Throttle

panels.description: Represents the latency to a workload that is being caused by QoS throughput floor (expected) setting assigned to other workloads. If the QoS floor set on certain workloads use the majority of the bandwidth to guarantee the promised throughput, other workloads will be throttled and see more latency.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Latency from Qos Min

panels.description:
Represents delays caused by the cluster switches, cables, and adapters which physically connect clustered nodes. 

If the cluster interconnect component is in contention, it means high wait time for I/O requests at the cluster interconnect is impacting the latency of one or more workloads.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Latency from Cluster

panels.description: Represents the delays in the data/WAFL layer of ONTAP.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Latency from Backend

panels.description: Represents delays due to buffered write flushes, called consistency points (cp).
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Latency from CP (Consistency Point)

panels.description: Represents delays due to operations suspending on a delay mechanism. Typically this is diagnosed by NetApp Support.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Latency from Suspend

panels.description: Represents the software component in the cluster involved with I/O processing between the cluster and the cloud tier on which user data is stored. If the cloud latency component is in contention, it means that a large amount of reads from volumes that are hosted on the cloud tier are impacting the latency of one or more workloads.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Latency from Cloud

panels.description: Represents the delays in the network layer of ONTAP.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Latency from Frontend

panels.description: Represents delays due to mirroring writes to the NVRAM/NVLOG memory and to the HA partner NVRAM/NVLOG memory.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Latency from NVLog Mirroring

panels.description: Represents slowness due to attached hard drives or solid state drives.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Latency from Disk
QoS Resource Latency

panels.description: Size that is physically used in the volume, in bytes.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes Per Physical Space Used

panels.description: Sum of (physical-used, shared_refs, compression_saved_in_plane0, vbn_zero, future_blk_cnt), in bytes.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes Per Logical Space Used

panels.description: The virtual space used (includes volume reserves) before storage efficiency, in bytes.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes Per Volume Size Used

panels.description: Physical size of the volume, in bytes.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes Per Volume Total Size

panels.description: Available space for Snapshot copies from snap-reserve, in bytes.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes Per Snapshot Size Available

panels.description: Size in the volume that has been set aside as a reserve for Snapshot copy usage, in bytes.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes Per Snapshot Reserve Size

panels.description: Size available for Snapshot copies within the Snapshot copy reserve, in bytes.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes Per Snapshot Reserve Available

panels.description: The total space used by Snapshot copies in the volume, in bytes.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes Per Snapshot Size Used

panels.description: The size that is physically used in the performance tier of the volume and has a cold temperature. This parameter is only supported if the volume is in an aggregate that is either attached to an object store or could be attached to an object store.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Inactive Data
Capacity

panels.description: Average latency per GET operation to object storage.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Object Storage GET Latency

panels.description: Total GET request count, per volume, in the collection interval to object storage.  Not scaled per second, but a cumulative count (delta) since the previous poll.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Object Storage GET Request Count

panels.description: Average latency per PUT operation to object storage.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Object Storage PUT Latency

panels.description: Total PUT request count, per volume, in the collection interval to object storage.  Not scaled per second, but a cumulative count (delta) since the previous poll.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Object Storage PUT Request Count

panels.description: Average request count, per volume, in the chosen time window, to object storage.  Not scaled per second, but a cumulative count (delta) since the previous poll.

targets.expr:
sum by (volume) (fabricpool_cloud_bin_operation{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume"}) 
  and 
topk($TopResources, sum by (volume) (avg_over_time(fabricpool_cloud_bin_operation{datacenter=~"$Datacenter",cluster=~"$Cluster",svm=~"$SVM",volume=~"$Volume"}[3h] @ end())))

panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Object Storage Requests
Object Storage

panels.description: Footprint of blocks written to the volume in bytes for the performance tier (bin 0).
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Performance Tier Footprint

panels.description: Footprint of blocks written to the volume in performance tier (bin 0) as a percentage of aggregate size.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Performance Tier Footprint %

panels.description: Footprint of blocks written to the volume in bytes for capacity tier (bin 1).
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Capacity Tier Footprint

panels.description: Footprint of blocks written to the volume in capacity tier (bin 1) as a percentage of aggregate size.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Capacity Tier Footprint %
FabricPool

panels.description: Number of user-visible files (inodes) used. This field is valid only when the volume is online.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Inode Files Used

panels.description: Total user-visible file (inode) count, i.e., current maximum number of user-visible files (inodes) that this volume can currently hold.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Inode Files Total

panels.description: volume_inode_files_used / volume_inode_total.
panels.title: Top $TopResources Volumes by Inode Files Used Percentage
Inode
